information: Historically, maintaining a .400 batting average is extremely rare in modern baseball. No MLB player has finished a season batting .400 since Ted Williams in 1941. Furthermore, no player in the last 25 seasons has had a batting average of .400 or greater on July 1. In 2023, Luis Arraez's average was .401 on June 23 but fell to .392 by July 1. Factors contributing to this difficulty include lower league-wide Batting Average on Balls in Play (BABIP), which is .288 in the current era compared to .300 in 1930.

The case of Luis Arraez in 2023 is especially instructive: he was batting .401 on June 23 but declined to .392 by July 1 - just 8 days later. This demonstrates how difficult it is to maintain such a high average even for elite contact hitters. Structural factors in modern baseball compound this difficulty, including lower league-wide BABIP (.288 vs .300 historically), improved pitching, defensive shifts, and better scouting. By May 20, the MLB season is about 40-50 games in, and by July 1 players will have approximately 80-85 games of data. While early-season small samples can produce extreme averages, the next 6 weeks provide substantial time for regression to the mean. My forecast is not higher because: (1) the 25+ year drought is compelling evidence of extreme rarity, (2) even recent elite hitters haven't achieved this, (3) approximately 40 days remain for regression, and (4) structural baseball factors work against this outcome. My forecast is not lower because: (1) we're already 1.5-2 months into the season so we're past tiny sample sizes, (2) only ONE player out of 300+ MLB hitters needs to achieve this, (3) exceptional variance and hot streaks do occur in baseball, and (4) without current data on May 20 batting averages, I cannot rule out that someone is very close right now.
